awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Delineation of populations, species, and genomic adaptations across a widely distributed venomous snake species complex
awd_abstract_narration:
Characterizing the diversity and relatedness of life is an important goal of evolutionary biology, and our understanding of this diversity provides a framework to address important questions. Many of these questions relate to adaptations that are evolved over time to better suit organisms to their environment. In particular, it is little understood whether the same evolutionary forces and processes may act in a similar manner to produce locally adapted traits in closely related lineages. Are certain genes or genomic regions repeatedly targeted by natural selection across species that occupy drastically different habitats and climates? This research aims to address these questions using a unique system of North American rattlesnakes, the Crotalus viridis species complex. Snakes of this group are highly diverse in their coloration, size, and venom composition, and thrive in diverse ecoregions. This research program will generate a robust understanding of the evolutionary relationships among members of this group, which will also provide a contextual framework for testing hypotheses of how natural selection has driven their diversification. This research program will then use information collected from throughout the genomes of these lineages to look for evidence of genes and sets of genes that are common targets of selection for local adaptation.

Understanding the systematics of species complexes can be challenging, but new and robust analytical approaches, together with large genome-scale datasets from next-generation sequencing technology are making this challenge increasingly manageable. Despite the difficulties inherent in studying species complexes, these systems are ideal for linking our understanding of their biodiversity with the genomic processes that have shaped their evolution and diversity. This project seeks to make these connections using a comparative phylogenetic system, the Crotalus viridis species complex. The research program will generate the first robust species tree for the complex, which has historically been a problematic group for systematists, using genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism data. This phylogenetic framework will then be used as a comparative platform for analyses of genes and genomic regions under selection within and among lineages. This research will interrogate the genomes of multiple populations and species to address the question of whether selection regimes target common loci across such a species complex, or if genes and functional categories of genes are idiosyncratically targeted by lineage. Collectively, this research will characterize the evolutionary history of a diverse and medically relevant venomous snake group and will add considerably to our knowledge of the roles that adaptation and convergent evolution play in the generation of biodiversity at multiple scales.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported research focused on identifying patterns of genetic variation related to speciation and adaptation in a venomous snake species complex. Venomous snakes are highly medically relevant study species due to the potency and diversity of biological targets of venom components. Specifically, the focal species complex of the research supported by this award harbors some of the most tremendous variation in venom composition known in snakes. Additionally, this system offers excellent opportunities to better understand population genetic patterns of divergence and introgression and how they relate to speciation and adaptation, as the lineages within this complex exist on a ‘continuum’ of divergence.

The project supported by this award focused on the Western Rattlesnake (Crotalus viridis) species complex, a group comprised of nine currently recognized subspecies, and their sister taxon Crotalus scutulatus. Estimating the phylogeography of this group has been problematic over the last two decades, and researchers have reached little consensus regarding their relationships. To address this issue, we have generated robust mitochondrial gene and next-generation restriction digest associated DNA sequencing (RADseq) datasets using funds from this award. We have also generated such datasets for close relatives of this species complex, including the Western Diamondback Rattlesnake (Crotalus atrox). Work with these data is ongoing, and is expected to result in multiple publications of value to our understanding of population genetic patterns of speciation and adaptation in widely distributed vertebrates. The ultimate goal of this research is, provided a strong framework of understanding regarding the evolutionary history of this group, to use this system as comparative framework to test hypotheses about repeated patterns of adaptation across the speciation continuum. In this way, we hope to understand if distantly related lineages subject to similar environments and selection pressures exhibit consistent genomic patterns of selection. We also aim to understand if the same genomic regions are repeatedly important for adaptation, regardless of a lineages’ specific environment.

We have published two manuscripts (with a third in review) related to this work, where we have demonstrated our analyses of phylogenetics, phylogeography, gene flow, hybridization, and selection on closely related taxa (i.e., Crotalus atrox and Crotalus scutulatus). These papers serve as an example of the types of tests and analyses we will perform on our combined mitochondrial and genomic datasets for the Crotalus viridis species complex. We anticipate publishing the first paper focused solely on this species complex early next year. This award has also indirectly contributed to several published works related to genomics, population genetics, phylogeography, and phylogenetics of other snake systems, as well as the tropical disease causing flatworm Schistosoma japonicum. Beyond these studies, this award has enabled work on the high quality Prairie Rattlesnake (Crotalus viridis) genome, which we plan to publish this fall. This genome will serve as a foundational resource for additional studies of this system, and the most highly contiguous, high quality reptile genome that we are aware of, making it of general value to the genomics community.

Overall, this award has enabled a tremendous amount of scientific productivity that is of value to basic science and has medical relevance due to the venomous nature of the focal organism. We anticipate completing all data collection, analyses, and papers relevant to the proposal for this award within the year. The data collected under this award will be of great value for additional studies on this system, as well as broader studies of next-generation sequencing data.

Modified by: Todd A Castoe
